summary: "Bureau Informant 100" refers to a procedure established by the FBI in 1954 for handling information received from James Angleton of the CIA. This information was largely sourced from a liaison arrangement with the Israeli Intelligence Service. The FBI memos discuss the handling of this sensitive information, including the establishment of a separate control file and later the recommendation to discontinue it as the information was already recorded in separate case files. The memos also address the method of forwarding the information from the CIA, specifically by courier in sealed envelopes. The procedure was used to handle SCOPE material, which refers to Israeli intelligence activities.
significance: While the documents do not explicitly link "Bureau Informant 100" to the JFK assassination, the procedure was used to handle sensitive information from James Angleton of the CIA, largely sourced from a liaison arrangement with the Israeli Intelligence Service. The documents suggest that the information was considered sensitive and required special handling procedures. The significance in the JFK context would depend on whether any of the information handled under this procedure was relevant to the assassination investigation.
